ports_protocols.description: Used to transfer files across a network in active mode.
Used to establish a connection and send commands for file transfers.
Provides secure, encrypted remote access to the command-line interface of a host.
Provides unsecure, unencrypted remote access to the command-line interface of a host.
Used for unsecure message relay between Simple Mail Transfer Protocol servers.
Resolves friendly host names and fully qualified domain names to IP addresses.
Used by a server to provision IP address configurations and options to clients.
Used by a client to request a dynamic IP address configuration from a DHCP server.
Enables clients to request and receive unsecure web pages and resources.
An early mailbox access protocol used to retrieve email by downloading it to a local device.
Legacy Windows protocol used for name resolution over a local network.
Legacy Windows protocol used to establish sessions for services like file sharing.
A mailbox access protocol that supports permanent connections and managing mail on the server.
Used by management systems to query status information from network device agents.
Used by network device agents to report notable events or alerts to a management system.
Used to query and update a centralized X.500-based directory of network users and resources.
Uses TLS/SSL to provide secure, encrypted access to websites and web services.
Supports file and printer sharing on Windows networks, often called CIFS.
Modern secure port used by mail clients to submit messages for delivery using encryption.
Secure version of IMAP that uses TLS to encrypt mail retrieval and management.
Secure version of POP3 that uses TLS to encrypt the retrieval of email messages.
Microsoft protocol for secure remote graphical desktop connections.

command_line.scenario: Used to display detailed TCP/IP configuration information, including DHCP and DNS server addresses and the MAC address.
Used to test connectivity to another host or verify that the local TCP/IP stack is installed correctly by pinging the loopback address.
Used to trace the route a packet takes to a destination, identifying every router (hop) and measuring latency at each point.
A more advanced version of tracert that pings each hop over a period to measure link latency and packet loss more accurately.
Returns the specific name configured for the local computer, which is necessary for clients to access its shared resources.
Used to view active network connections and the specific software processes or applications associated with them.
Operates in an interactive mode to troubleshoot and verify DNS name resolution records.
Lists the files and subdirectories in the current directory, with /p used to display results page by page.
Used to change the current working directory; 'cd ..' moves the focus up one level to the parent directory.
Used to transfer files from a source path to a destination path within a single directory.
A legacy utility used to copy directory structures and their contents to another location.
The 'Robust Copy' tool recommended for modern scripting to move or copy files while preserving NTFS attributes and long filenames.
Used to create a new directory at the specified path.
Used to remove a directory; the /s switch allows for the deletion of a directory that is not empty.
A command-line interface for managing disks, partitions, and volumes, often used when the GUI Disk Management tool is unavailable.
Writes a new file system to a drive, effectively deleting all existing data on that partition.
Scans the file system for errors and attempts to fix them; /r can additionally be used to recover data from bad sectors.
The System File Checker verifies the integrity of protected Windows system files and restores them from cache if they are corrupt.
Used in the recovery environment to repair the Master Boot Record (MBR), boot sector, or the Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store.
Safely halts the system or initiates a restart; /t can be used to specify a delay in seconds.
Used for diagnostic startups to troubleshoot which services or programs are causing boot issues.
The Registry Editor allows technicians to view and manually edit the database of Windows configuration settings.
The Group Policy Editor used to configure and enforce OS and application settings across a domain or local machine.
Used to monitor real-time resource utilization (CPU, RAM, Disk) and end unresponsive tasks or processes.
Generates a comprehensive inventory of the system's hardware resources, software environment, and components.
A simple command to report the current Windows brand, version, and OS build number.
Used to manually edit the Boot Configuration Data (BCD) store to add or modify boot paths.
Used to re-register dynamic link library (DLL) components that a background service relies upon.
